html:
b'
Dear Members of the University Senate and Senate Executive Committee,

Please see the below email for the upcoming visits by candidates for the UOPD's Chief of Police position. Please note that tomorrow is the first in a series of visits. There is also a link provided below to provide feedback via an online survey after each candidate's visit.

Please contact Kelly McIver with any and all questions regarding this search or the various candidate visits at Kelly.McIver at uopd.org<mailto:Kelly.McIver at uopd.org>.

Best,

Betina

Betina Lynn
Executive Coordinator, University Senate

From: Kelly McIver [mailto:Kelly.McIver at uopd.org]
Sent: Friday, July 08, 2016 3:55 PM

Subject: Please attend UOPD police chief candidate campus visits!

Members and Leadership in University Senate:

Candidates for the UOPD's next Chief of Police will visit campus soon, and members of the faculty and other institution stakeholders are strongly encouraged to attend and deliver feedback.

Available candidate information, schedules, and ultimately an online feedback form, can be found here:

http://police.uoregon.edu/content/uopd-chief-candidates-visit-campus

The first candidate will be on campus next Tuesday, July 12. The next will be Friday, July 15. The third and final candidate will be July 25. Here are the opportunities to attend events with the candidates, and ask questions:

Tuesday, July 12 - Candidate A (James Miyashiro)
Public presentation with Q&A -- 2:30-3:30 p.m. in Susan Campbell Hall 111
Faculty and staff Q&A -- 3:40-4:25 p.m. in Susan Campbell Hall 111

Friday, July 15 - Candidate B (to be published July 13)
Public presentation with Q&A -- 2:30-3:30 p.m. in the Knight Library Browsing Room
Faculty and staff Q&A --  3:40-4:25 p.m. in the Knight Library Browsing Room

Monday, July 25 - Candidate C (to be published July 21)
Public presentation with Q&A -- 2:30-3:30 p.m. in the Knight Library Browsing Room
Faculty and staff Q&A -- 3:40-4:25 p.m. in the Knight Library Browsing Room

PLEASE PASS THIS ON TO INTERESTED COLLEAGUES and encourage them to attend the sessions above, and provide feedback through the online form that will be posted to the link above, at the time of each visit.

Thanks,

Kelly

subject: b'[Uosenateexec] Announcement: Senate Responsible Reporting Working\tGroup'
html:
b'
Dear Senators - 

We\xe2\x80\x99ve set up a working group to rewrite the Responsible Employees Policy, as follows. It is a small group, but it will consult with all Senate constituents.

Charge: 

The Senate Responsible Reporting Working Group is tasked with drafting a new Responsible Employees Policy for the Senate and Administration to consider as a replacement for the current emergency policy. The working group will follow the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s normal open meetings rules, and will solicit input broadly from the Administration, the Senate, and the university community, and will hold at least one town hall type meeting for this purpose. The working group may seek outside advice, particularly on considerations involving compliance with applicable laws and regulations. The draft policy sent to the Senate will be accompanied by a document explaining the rationale for the recommended rules and procedures. 

Membership:

Merle Weiner, Professor, Law (Chair)
Phyllis Barkhurst, OA, Director of 90by30, Co-Director of the UO Center for the Prevention of Abuse and Neglect
Jennifer Freyd, Professor, Psychology
Bill Harbaugh, Professor, Economics
Darci Heroy, OA, Interim Title IX Coordinator
and a student member, TBA.

Yours, 

Bill Harbaugh
University of Oregon
Econ Prof, Senate Pres

subject: b'[Uosenateexec] Women in Oregon -- what is our academic\tresponsibility?'
html:
b'
Dear Senate Executive Committee Colleagues,

A new report indicates Oregon's rates of sexual & domestic violence are particularly high when compared to other states.

Report: Oregon Has Very High Rate Of Female Sexual Assault
http://www.opb.org/news/article/sexual-assault-high-rate-oregon-women-girls-report/

The OPB story notes about the report:

Researchers used data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to reach some startling conclusions. Among them: Just over half of the state's female population has been the victim of sexual or domestic violence.

The report itself (which documents many additional injustices that women face in Oregon) is available at:
https://womensfoundationoforegon.org/count-her-in

Perhaps we could discuss at one of our meetings the possible implications of these findings for our academic mission.

Jennifer

In my view, the \xe2\x80\x9cAcceptable Use Policy\xe2\x80\x9d for IT resources definitely includes
academic matters. 

Paragraph 1.0 states for employees that \xe2\x80\x9cincidental and personal use\xe2\x80\x9d of  UO
IT Resources \xe2\x80\x9cmay be permitted if it is minimal.\xe2\x80\x9d  The term \xe2\x80\x9cmay be\xe2\x80\x9d appears
to leave unlimited discretion in the hands of someone other than the user to
restrict such use at various times and for various reasons.  It does not say
\xe2\x80\x9cis permitted.\xe2\x80\x9d  This can impact a professor\xe2\x80\x99s or student\xe2\x80\x99s ability at
expression and speech.

Furthermore, paragraph 1.0 has two standards:  use must be \xe2\x80\x9cminimal\xe2\x80\x9d and use
must \xe2\x80\x9cnot interfere with UO\xe2\x80\x99s or the employee\xe2\x80\x99s ability to carry out UO
business.\xe2\x80\x9d  As long as the use does not interfere, there is no reason for
the additional restriction that such use be \xe2\x80\x9cminimal.\xe2\x80\x9d  And of course
\xe2\x80\x9cminimal\xe2\x80\x9d has no clear meaning.

Paragraph 4.0 covers \xe2\x80\x9cappropriate uses.\xe2\x80\x9d  It is obvious today that,
regardless of Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s disdain for computers, the use of a computer is
quintessentially a central aspect of academic work in today\xe2\x80\x99s world.

Paragraph 4.2 states three standards for UO employees that are additional to
those found in paragraph 1.0.  Paragraph 4.2 says that personal use must be
\xe2\x80\x9cincidental,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccannot interfere with the fulfillment of the employee\xe2\x80\x99s job
responsibilities\xe2\x80\x9d (rather than the ability to carry out UO business), and
cannot \xe2\x80\x9cdisrupt the work environment.\xe2\x80\x9d

Paragraph 4.3 creates a completely different standard for students, allowing
use of UO IT Resources for anything the student wants, as long as not
conflicting with other elements of the Policy (or other UO policies).
Personal use by students need not be \xe2\x80\x9cminimal\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cincidental\xe2\x80\x9d or restrained
from interfering with UO\xe2\x80\x99s ability to carry out its business, apparently.

Paragraph 5.1 references Oregon Revised Statutes section 260.432, but
conspicuously fails to mention that this section of law includes this: "
this section does not restrict the right of a public employee to express
personal political views."

By not including this provision of the law, paragraph 5.1 is misleading to
faculty, staff, and students.

Paragraph 6.6 goes beyond the allowable limits of the Constitution of the
State of Oregon\xe2\x80\x99s guarantee of freedom of expression.  It lists several
characteristics that an email should not have if a \xe2\x80\x9crecipient\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9canother
viewer\xe2\x80\x9d could \xe2\x80\x9creasonably\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cconsider[]\xe2\x80\x9d the email to have those
characteristics.  The freedom of expression provision of the Oregon
Constitution, as interpreted by the courts do not allow this standard to be
imposed at least on students and perhaps on professors.  Paragraph 6.6
allows retaliatory actions by University administrators against students and
professors, for example, who discuss issue of homosexuality, race, and other
matters, if the administrator decides that any viewer of the email could
reasonably consider that discussion to be objectionable within the terms of
the policy.  This directly contradicts the UO policies on Academic Freedom
and Freedom of Expression.\xe2\x80\x9d  These are clearly and definitely \xe2\x80\x9cacademic
matters.\xe2\x80\x9d

John

subject: b'[Uosenateexec] FW: Free to Be You and Me: Autonomy Privacy in\tHigher Education'
html:
b'
A colleagues sent me this short Educause article that makes an important distinction between data privacy and autonomy privacy. The author is the university privacy officer and interim CISO at the University of Michigan.  I thought you might find this interesting and relevant to our work.

 http://er.educause.edu/blogs/2017/1/free-to-be-you-and-me-autonomy-privacy-in-higher-education

Free to Be You and Me: Autonomy Privacy in Higher Education
Authors:
by Sol Bermann<http://members.educause.edu/sol-bermann>
Published:
Tuesday, January 17, 2017
Columns:
Security Matters <http://er.educause.edu/columns/security-matters>

January 28 is Data Privacy Day<http://www.educause.edu/dpd>. Throughout the months of January and February, the EDUCAUSE Cybersecurity Initiative will highlight higher education privacy issues. To learn more, visit StaySafeOnline<http://staysafeonline.org/data-privacy-day/>.

Computerization is robbing individuals of the ability to monitor and control the ways information about them is used\xe2\x80\xa6.The foundation is being laid for a dossier society, in which computers could be used to infer individuals\xe2\x80\x99 life-styles, habits, whereabouts, and associations from data collected in ordinary consumer transactions. Uncertainty about whether data will remain secure against abuse by those maintaining or tapping it can have a \xe2\x80\x9cchilling effect,\xe2\x80\x9d causing people to alter their observable activities.
\xe2\x80\x94David Chaum, 19851


Higher education rightfully prides itself as being a place where freedom of expression, intellectual discourse, dissenting views, and social experimentation are not just the norm but expected. The ability to engage in any or all of these activities is best done when an individual is not concerned with being (potentially or actually) under surveillance \xe2\x80\x94 as Chaum recognized, surveillance can have a \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98chilling effect,\xe2\x80\x99 causing people to alter their observable activities.\xe2\x80\x9d

Privacy professionals often think of privacy in two distinct but occasionally interrelated categories:

  1.  Data Privacy: Having to do with the collection, use, and sharing of information about individuals. Most of the privacy-related laws we are familiar with (FERPA<http://library.educause.edu/topics/policy-and-law/family-educational-rights-and-privacy-act-ferpa>, HIPAA<http://library.educause.edu/topics/policy-and-law/health-insurance-portability-and-accountability-act-hipaa>, etc.) fall into the data privacy category.
  2.  Autonomy Privacy:2 Having to do with the ability of individuals to be free of actual or potential observation. Autonomy privacy is strongly tied to freedom of thought, association, expression, and other civil and individual liberties and is most often associated with use of surveillance activities like audio/video capture.

In the digital age, we all too often focus on data privacy and its legal and compliance requirements. In doing so we forget the dictionary definition of privacy<http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/privacy> (which includes \xe2\x80\x9cbeing apart from\xe2\x80\xa6observation\xe2\x80\x9d), and risk losing track of how pervasive and quickly data collection, big data, and data science are creating autonomy-privacy issues that can impact free expression or dissenting views as much as pervasive security cameras or wiretaps.

There was of course no way of knowing whether you were being watched at any given moment. How often, or on what system...they could plug in your wire whenever they wanted.
\xe2\x80\x94George Orwell, 19481

Every boy in this land grows to be his own man.

In this land, every girl grows to be her own woman.
\xe2\x80\x94Bruce Hart, 19723


What does it mean to be under threat of constant surveillance? Why is it particularly important for colleges and universities to recognize, as the University of California system explicitly did<http://www.ucop.edu/ethics-compliance-audit-services/_files/compliance/uc-privacy-principles.pdf>, that privacy must also be defined as being free from surveillance?

In 1984, George Orwell wrote about a bleak world where citizen control was predicated on perpetual surveillance (actual or assumed). In his version of the Panopticon<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panopticon>, plugging into \xe2\x80\x9cyour wire\xe2\x80\x9d meant the government could be watching you at any time via cameras or your own TV, eerily foreshadowing a world where the NSA and others have the ability to spy using webcams<http://abcnews.go.com/Business/webcam-spying-stop/story?id=27092216>.

<image001.png>The Panopticon is a marvelous machine which, whatever use one may wish to put it to, produces homogeneous effects of power. Michel Foucault<http://foucault.info/doc/documents/disciplineandpunish/foucault-disciplineandpunish-panopticism-html>

There is more to lose even if you think you have nothing to hide!


In his book Surveillance Studies<http://soc.sagepub.com/content/43/3/585.full.pdf+html>, Professor David Lyon<http://www.sscqueens.org/people/david-lyon> defines surveillance as \xe2\x80\x9cthe focused, systematic and routine attention to personal details for purposes of influence, management, protection or direction.\xe2\x80\x9d He adds that \xe2\x80\x9csurveillance is primarily about power, but it is also about personhood.\xe2\x80\x9d

The debilitating effects of surveillance on personhood or an individual are legion. Research<http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1048984310001943> has shown time<http://harvardlawreview.org/2013/05/the-dangers-of-surveillance/> and time<http://www.lemauricien.com/article/negative-effects-cctv-workplace-surveillance> and time<http://psychology.about.com/od/classicpsychologystudies/p/conformity.htm> again<http://cs.stanford.edu/people/eroberts/cs181/projects/ethics-of-surveillance/ethics.html> that the threat of constant surveillance can lead to individual stress, conforming behavior, intolerance of differences, curtailment of free speech and association, devaluing of individualism, and squashing of dissent.

Taken further, if we believe social scientist Irwin Altman\xe2\x80\x99s statement that \xe2\x80\x9cbuilding and maintaining an enduring, intimate relationship is a process of privacy regulation<http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/05/sunday-review/we-want-privacy-but-cant-stop-sharing.html?_r=0>,\xe2\x80\x9d then surveillance restricts and/or damage personal relationships (which is exactly what happened to characters Winston and Julia in Orwell\xe2\x80\x99s 1984).

Now think about the world of higher education:

  *   Students as young adults, learning through trial and error, experimenting and exploring, growing as individuals, creating some of their first intimate adult relationships, making mistakes, taking social and political positions, discovering themselves through academics and social interaction. Without autonomy privacy, could every boy in this land grow to be his own man or every girl grow to be her own woman?4
  *   Faculty and researchers researching through trial and error, experimenting and exploring, making mistakes, making and taking social and political positions. Is it any wonder that Fascist states, from Stalin to Hitler to Salazar to Honecker to Peron, relied on surveillance and suppressed academic freedom?

And in the End

Colleges and universities are supposed to be bastions of creativity and intellectual freedom, places where cutting-edge and sometimes controversial thought and research take place on a daily basis. In addition, historically they are often cradles and hotbeds of protest, dissent, and free expression. Privacy feeds those traits, which is why it has traditionally been a closely held value in higher education (so much so that during the course of privacy stakeholder conversations at the University of Michigan, one now-retired executive responded to my question \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think privacy is important or valued at U of M?\xe2\x80\x9d by staring at me with a puzzled expression and stating \xe2\x80\x9cI have never considered it, because I have always assumed it was\xe2\x80\x9d).

If we lose track of privacy in higher education, what does that mean for the rest of society going forward? What inventions or sociopolitical voices might be lost without privacy being a part of the higher education culture?

I would like to see our colleges and universities double down on privacy and explicitly discuss its importance and value in the academy, and the world in general. Higher education is uniquely positioned to engage in multidisciplinary collaborations that tie together the legal, sociopolitical, historical, and technical aspects of privacy. I would like to see faculty, researchers, higher education privacy officers, and other stakeholders work together to educate and empower their community, in particular students, by teaching them privacy\xe2\x80\x99s vital role in self and society, and train them to be privacy conscious. In short, privacy matters.

Notes

  1.  David Chaum, \xe2\x80\x9cSecurity without Identification: Transaction Systems to Make Big Brother Obsolete<http://www.cs.umd.edu/class/fall2015/cmsc414-0201/papers/chaum-identification.pdf>,\xe2\x80\x9d Communications of the ACM 28, no. 10, October 1985.
  2.  The traditional, legal definition of autonomy privacy is tied to the freedom of individuals to choose whether or not to engage in certain acts or activities (often tied to sexual or reproductive rights). For purposes of this blog, I am using the University of California system Privacy and Information Security Steering Committee Report<http://ucop.edu/privacy-initiative/uc-privacy-and-information-security-steering-committee-final-report.pdf> definition of autonomy privacy, which is \xe2\x80\x9can individual\xe2\x80\x99s ability to conduct activities without concern of or actual observation.\xe2\x80\x9d
  3.  These lyrics are from a song titled "Free To Be... You And Me" written by Bruce Hart. The song was included as part of the 1972 album and project of the same name<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_to_Be..._You_and_Me>. The title of this blog acknowledges this project and song.
  4.  Ibid.

________________________________

Sol Bermann is the university privacy officer and interim CISO at the University of Michigan.

Higher education rightfully prides itself as being a place where freedom of expression, intellectual discourse, dissenting views, and social experimentation are not just the norm but expected. The ability to engage in any or all of these activities is best done when an individual is not concerned with being (potentially or actually) under surveillance \xe2\x80\x94 as Chaum recognized, surveillance can have a \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98chilling effect,\xe2\x80\x99 causing people to alter their observable activities.\xe2\x80\x9d

Privacy professionals often think of privacy in two distinct but occasionally interrelated categories:

  1.  Data Privacy: Having to do with the collection, use, and sharing of information about individuals. Most of the privacy-related laws we are familiar with (FERPA<http://library.educause.edu/topics/policy-and-law/family-educational-rights-and-privacy-act-ferpa>, HIPAA<http://library.educause.edu/topics/policy-and-law/health-insurance-portability-and-accountability-act-hipaa>, etc.) fall into the data privacy category.
  2.  Autonomy Privacy:2 Having to do with the ability of individuals to be free of actual or potential observation. Autonomy privacy is strongly tied to freedom of thought, association, expression, and other civil and individual liberties and is most often associated with use of surveillance activities like audio/video capture.

In the digital age, we all too often focus on data privacy and its legal and compliance requirements. In doing so we forget the dictionary definition of privacy<http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/privacy> (which includes \xe2\x80\x9cbeing apart from\xe2\x80\xa6observation\xe2\x80\x9d), and risk losing track of how pervasive and quickly data collection, big data, and data science are creating autonomy-privacy issues that can impact free expression or dissenting views as much as pervasive security cameras or wiretaps.

There was of course no way of knowing whether you were being watched at any given moment. How often, or on what system...they could plug in your wire whenever they wanted.
\xe2\x80\x94George Orwell, 19481

Every boy in this land grows to be his own man.

In this land, every girl grows to be her own woman.
\xe2\x80\x94Bruce Hart, 19723


What does it mean to be under threat of constant surveillance? Why is it particularly important for colleges and universities to recognize, as the University of California system explicitly did<http://www.ucop.edu/ethics-compliance-audit-services/_files/compliance/uc-privacy-principles.pdf>, that privacy must also be defined as being free from surveillance?

In 1984, George Orwell wrote about a bleak world where citizen control was predicated on perpetual surveillance (actual or assumed). In his version of the Panopticon<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panopticon>, plugging into \xe2\x80\x9cyour wire\xe2\x80\x9d meant the government could be watching you at any time via cameras or your own TV, eerily foreshadowing a world where the NSA and others have the ability to spy using webcams<http://abcnews.go.com/Business/webcam-spying-stop/story?id=27092216>.

<image001.png>The Panopticon is a marvelous machine which, whatever use one may wish to put it to, produces homogeneous effects of power. Michel Foucault<http://foucault.info/doc/documents/disciplineandpunish/foucault-disciplineandpunish-panopticism-html>

There is more to lose even if you think you have nothing to hide!


In his book Surveillance Studies<http://soc.sagepub.com/content/43/3/585.full.pdf+html>, Professor David Lyon<http://www.sscqueens.org/people/david-lyon> defines surveillance as \xe2\x80\x9cthe focused, systematic and routine attention to personal details for purposes of influence, management, protection or direction.\xe2\x80\x9d He adds that \xe2\x80\x9csurveillance is primarily about power, but it is also about personhood.\xe2\x80\x9d

The debilitating effects of surveillance on personhood or an individual are legion. Research<http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1048984310001943> has shown time<http://harvardlawreview.org/2013/05/the-dangers-of-surveillance/> and time<http://www.lemauricien.com/article/negative-effects-cctv-workplace-surveillance> and time<http://psychology.about.com/od/classicpsychologystudies/p/conformity.htm> again<http://cs.stanford.edu/people/eroberts/cs181/projects/ethics-of-surveillance/ethics.html> that the threat of constant surveillance can lead to individual stress, conforming behavior, intolerance of differences, curtailment of free speech and association, devaluing of individualism, and squashing of dissent.

Taken further, if we believe social scientist Irwin Altman\xe2\x80\x99s statement that \xe2\x80\x9cbuilding and maintaining an enduring, intimate relationship is a process of privacy regulation<http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/05/sunday-review/we-want-privacy-but-cant-stop-sharing.html?_r=0>,\xe2\x80\x9d then surveillance restricts and/or damage personal relationships (which is exactly what happened to characters Winston and Julia in Orwell\xe2\x80\x99s 1984).

Now think about the world of higher education:

  *   Students as young adults, learning through trial and error, experimenting and exploring, growing as individuals, creating some of their first intimate adult relationships, making mistakes, taking social and political positions, discovering themselves through academics and social interaction. Without autonomy privacy, could every boy in this land grow to be his own man or every girl grow to be her own woman?4
  *   Faculty and researchers researching through trial and error, experimenting and exploring, making mistakes, making and taking social and political positions. Is it any wonder that Fascist states, from Stalin to Hitler to Salazar to Honecker to Peron, relied on surveillance and suppressed academic freedom?

And in the End

Colleges and universities are supposed to be bastions of creativity and intellectual freedom, places where cutting-edge and sometimes controversial thought and research take place on a daily basis. In addition, historically they are often cradles and hotbeds of protest, dissent, and free expression. Privacy feeds those traits, which is why it has traditionally been a closely held value in higher education (so much so that during the course of privacy stakeholder conversations at the University of Michigan, one now-retired executive responded to my question \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think privacy is important or valued at U of M?\xe2\x80\x9d by staring at me with a puzzled expression and stating \xe2\x80\x9cI have never considered it, because I have always assumed it was\xe2\x80\x9d).

If we lose track of privacy in higher education, what does that mean for the rest of society going forward? What inventions or sociopolitical voices might be lost without privacy being a part of the higher education culture?

I would like to see our colleges and universities double down on privacy and explicitly discuss its importance and value in the academy, and the world in general. Higher education is uniquely positioned to engage in multidisciplinary collaborations that tie together the legal, sociopolitical, historical, and technical aspects of privacy. I would like to see faculty, researchers, higher education privacy officers, and other stakeholders work together to educate and empower their community, in particular students, by teaching them privacy\xe2\x80\x99s vital role in self and society, and train them to be privacy conscious. In short, privacy matters.

Notes

  1.  David Chaum, \xe2\x80\x9cSecurity without Identification: Transaction Systems to Make Big Brother Obsolete<http://www.cs.umd.edu/class/fall2015/cmsc414-0201/papers/chaum-identification.pdf>,\xe2\x80\x9d Communications of the ACM 28, no. 10, October 1985.
  2.  The traditional, legal definition of autonomy privacy is tied to the freedom of individuals to choose whether or not to engage in certain acts or activities (often tied to sexual or reproductive rights). For purposes of this blog, I am using the University of California system Privacy and Information Security Steering Committee Report<http://ucop.edu/privacy-initiative/uc-privacy-and-information-security-steering-committee-final-report.pdf> definition of autonomy privacy, which is \xe2\x80\x9can individual\xe2\x80\x99s ability to conduct activities without concern of or actual observation.\xe2\x80\x9d
  3.  These lyrics are from a song titled "Free To Be... You And Me" written by Bruce Hart. The song was included as part of the 1972 album and project of the same name<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_to_Be..._You_and_Me>. The title of this blog acknowledges this project and song.
  4.  Ibid.

b'
Dear Members of the Senate Executive Committee,

Welcome to the 2019-2020 year!

Hopefully you all received the calendar invites for these meetings from me earlier this week. Our first meeting is scheduled for next Wednesday, September 25, 2019.

Subject: Oregon InC Funding Opportunities Forum: Monday 10/14
*Please distribute to your faculty and colleagues*

Good afternoon,

This coming Monday, 10/14, immediately following the State of Research presentation<https://around.uoregon.edu/content/conover-deliver-annual-talk-uo-research-accomplishments>, we invite you to join the Office of the Vice President for Research and Innovation for an open forum with Business Oregon/Oregon  InC<https://urldefense.com/v3/__https:/www.oregon4biz.com/Innovate-&-Create/Oregon-InC/__;!5W9E9PnL_ac!WUPRzTuZYWmXo_2XjtlsMw-6slw4Mbv-W39MDEsUqeae76R038dTiFFAeN4kvGbpw78$> to learn about their funding opportunities to support translational research, innovation, and commercialization.

When: Monday, October 14th,  3-3:45pm (directly following the State of Research)
Where: Erb Memorial Union, Swindells Room (230)

Oregon InC is a public-private partnership that helps create new jobs and new companies, diversifying Oregon's economy and bringing federal research dollars back to the state.  Mark Brady, Innovation Strategist, will present on the following opportunities available to University of Oregon faculty:
1.       SBIR Application Support and Matching Grants
2.       High-Impact Opportunity Projects
3.       University Innovation Research Fund

Dear Members of the University Senate and Senate Executive Committee,

There is a new Consent Calendar item for the November 13, 2019 Senate Meeting agenda.

For those unfamiliar with a consent calendar, this is a way to minimize senate meeting time spent on small non-controversial items that likely do not need to be debated before a vote takes place. The consent calendar was put in place as a practice by the Senate per US17/18-04: UO Senate Adoption of Consent Calendar<https://senate.uoregon.edu/2018/01/05/us1718-04-uo-senate-adoption-of-consent-calendar/>.
